newsitem.title: FRANCE: French CFDT union calls 24-hr savings bank strike.
newsitem.headline: French CFDT union calls 24-hr savings bank strike.

text.p: France's Socialist CFDT union said on Wednesday that it had called a one-day strike at the Caisses d'Epargne savings bank group to protest against any attempt by the Caisses to buy the CIC bank, which is being privatised.
The union said it would propose the 24-hour strike at an inter-union meeting on Wednesday.

If the proposal wins approval, the strike would be in early October, before the Caisses d'Epargne supervisory board meets to decide whether it would make a bid for CIC, which belongs to state-controlled insurer GAN, said Jean-Paul Halgand, CFDT representative at the Caisses d'Epargne.
"It would be for early October. We all agree on the need for action," Halgand said.
A CFDT statement said the central supervisory board of the Caisses grouping had postponed to October 7 from September 18 a decision on what stance to take on the CIC sale.
It alleged this had been done to try to muster a majority in favour of a deal and that a majority would not have materialised on September 18.
"We must fight this takeover," said the statement. Halgand repeated union fears of 5,000 job losses if a takeover went ahead.

The CFDT statement said other suitors including commerical banks Societe Generale and BNP did not want to pay too much for the group and that the Caisses should remain a group whose primary mandate was to serve the public interest rather than become a bank like the others.
The government launched a tender on August 5 for the sale of 67 percent of CIC and closing date for offers is October 7.
